https://prez.dev/description.@value: The types of physical samples that are used to undertake quality assurance (QA) and quality control (QC) checks at all stages of the sampling, preparation and analytical processes, and/or to retain representative material for future reference. Note that QA and QC are often used collectively as a single term, but are in fact distinct procedures: QA 'refers to defect prevention', i.e. ‘the protocols and procedures that ensure that sampling and assaying is completed to the required quality’, whereas QC 'refers to defect detection', i.e. ‘the use of control samples and statistical analysis to ensure that assay results are reliable’ (Graindorge, 2010, p. 112; https://www.usgs.gov/data-management/manage-quality). This vocabulary thus also encapsulates terminology covering sample representability.
A second sample collected from the crushed field sample after the material has been reduced to a gravel (also called 'coarse crush') and analysed in the same analytical batch as the primary sample.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A sample collected or generated under comparable conditions to the primary sample and used as an indicator of relative precision when analysed concurrently, or kept as a reference for future usage. It is useful to distinguish the stage at which the duplicate was collected, i.e. whether in the field (field duplicate) or at any stage of sample-mass reduction (e.g. during crushing and pulverisation for rock or sieving for soil and stream-sediment samples, i.e. coarse-crush duplicate, pulp duplicate, etc.).

https://prez.dev/description.@value: A sample collected or generated under comparable conditions to the primary sample and used as an indicator of relative precision when analysed concurrently, or kept as a reference for future usage. It is useful to distinguish the stage at which the duplicate was collected, i.e. whether in the field (field duplicate) or at any stage of sample-mass reduction (e.g. during crushing and pulverisation for rock or sieving for soil and stream-sediment samples, i.e. coarse-crush duplicate, pulp duplicate, etc.).

A second sample of equal size (mass) to the original, collected as close as possible to the location of the original sample under comparable conditions and using an identical sampling procedure. Field duplicates are typically collected at the same time as the original and analysed within the same analytical batch to ensure that the only difference in the results is related to the sampling variance.
A second weighing of a sample taken from the same container as the original under laboratory conditions and analysed in the same analytical batch.

A second sample collected from the pulverised field sample after the material has been reduced to a powder and analysed in the same analytical batch as the primary sample. Many laboratories identify these as repeats, which is a common source of confusion.
